oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Stella Parton Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Stella Parton (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Stella Parton; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie introduces, and Stella Parton addresses, "Always Tomorrow" as the title track -- (00:10) "I Don't Miss You Like I Used to" is considered by Parton to be a traditional song with 'Texas flavor;' Collie and Parton discuss how this was the first song she ever cut in the key of F -- (01:18) Parton discusses how "You Said You Loved Me" was the first song she wrote with her husband, recording engineer, Steve A. Messer -- (02:04) Collie and Parton discuss how Parton continues to work with Messer and how Parton started dating Messer while working together -- (02:25) Collie and Parton discuss the idea of "You Said You Loved Me" being a message to an ex, and Parton used it as an opportunity to gain favor with Messer -- (03:05) "Valley of Desire" is said to be a song dreamt up by Parton on her way to Australia -- (03:49) Collie and Parton discuss how Parton typically writes lyrics and the symbolism in "Valley of Desire" that came from Parton's dream -- (04:33) "Sisters" is told to be from Pump Boys and Dinettes; Parton recalls seeing "Sisters" being performed on Broadway, and Parton recalls thinking about how she wanted to perform it with Dolly Parton -- (05:54) Collie and Parton discuss how Parton and Dolly have recorded and performed together -- (06:48) Parton discusses how her uncle Billy Owens would teach Parton and her sisters about harmonizing and other vocal teachings -- (07:26) Parton tells about how Owens idolized Chet Atkins and how Owens would produce 'rockabilly' tracks during ten-hour recording stretches with the Parton sisters -- (08:44) Parton describes an incident where Cassie Parton would complain to Owens about bologna sandwiches and pickles -- (09:08) Collie introduces "You're the Reason I'm Living" as an older tune and Parton tells about how "You're the Reason I'm Living" is based on a poem by Bobby Lawrence -- (11:03) Parton discusses the difficulty of the music industry and the need for diversity -- (12:17) Parton discusses her variety show and claims her responsibility to demonstrate country to her patrons -- (13:24) Collie and Parton discuss her administrative role in Dolly Parton's publishing company and how Parton would re-cut Dolly's demos -- (14:48) "Saving My Love" is revealed to be Parton's next single that she loves to perform live due to its light-hearted nature; "Saving My Love" is revealed to have almost been the title track -- (16:47) Collie wishes to discuss Floyd Parton and Randy Parton, and Parton reveals there are twelve Parton siblings, only half of whom have musical careers -- (18:07) "Always Tomorrow" is discussed by by Parton to have been brought to her by her husband as a good harmonizing song written by Buddy Cannon -- (19:05) "Falling Again" writer Tim Wright is praised by Parton, and Parton states that "Falling Again" has a line that can make it a hit -- (20:12) "Anytime Man" is discussed by Parton to be a song that she had been performing for years to gain the feedback from the audience, and Parton discusses how she enjoys having a song that's a compliment to a man -- (21:38) Collie has Parton reflect on her successful stage career -- (23:36) Parton reflects on her offer to lead in Seven Brides for Seven Brothers -- (24:45) Parton reflects on the training gained from doing 114 shows of the Best Little Whore House in Texas -- (25:46) Parton says that she and Dolly had yet to perform together on stage -- (26:14) "Summertime Moon" is said to be 'new bluegrass' and Parton describes how the song was written on a computer -- (27:56) Parton says that she once went on stage with her shoes on the wrong feet -- (29:07) Collie tells about a rumor he heard, and Parton tells about how her mother would make banana pudding in a dish pan -- (30:17) Collie has Parton describe what a Vegetarian is -- (31:20) Parton describes her unreleased song "We Are Gypsies" and Parton tells how she ends each show with it -- (32:08) Parton says her goodbye in poem form and Collie invites her back
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Parton, Stella; Collie, Biff;
